Title: Canada, Mexico and China are set to respond to Trump's announcement of tariffs
Description: As President Trump announces tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China on Saturday night, we look at how those countries might respond.

Title: Pop-up health events in LA assist wildfire evacuees with medical needs
Description: People displaced by the LA wildfires found themselves needing help with basic health care — like getting medications lost in the fires. In El Monte, a pop-up health event provided some assistance.

Title: North Korean troops fighting for Russia in Ukraine appear to have pulled back
Description: Ukrainian soldiers have been saying for weeks that North Korean troops have been fighting alongside Russians. But it looks like those troops might be pulling back now.

Title: A stampede at India's largest Hindu religious gathering raises security questions
Description: A deadly stampede at a Hindu festival in India is causing many to wonder how to effectively manage massive events.

Title: Understnading the law at the heart of confusion over Trump's federal funding freeze
Description: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks with Georgetown Law professor Stephen Vladeck about the constitutional issues raised by the Trump administration's efforts to pause federal loans and grants last week.

Title: Life in Goma, the Congolese city under a new occupation
Description: A glimpse of life after the siege in the eastern Congolese city of Goma, as some semblance of a tenuous peace returns, as does the fear of reprisals.

Title: Tennessee's new anti-immigration measures signal the new normal for Republican states
Description: The Tennessee Legislature passed a series of anti-immigration measures including a law making it a crime for local officials to vote for sanctuary policies. The move comes as other Republican-led states are looking at similar ideas.

Title: What it's like to party in the native habitat of Groundhog Day star Punxsutawney Phil
Description: It was a big party in Punxsutawney this weekend. 'This is my favorite holiday,' one local says of the fuss-free day, adding, 'You don't have to even see your in-laws.' This year, Phil saw his shadow.

Title: Astronomers are tracking an asteroid that could hit Earth in 2032
Description: The odds are about 1% that the football field-sized object could hit the Earth, but that makes it the closest call in more than 20 years. (Image credit: Sergey Hametov)

Title: How did racist mass texts bypass some anti-spam guardrails after the election?
Description: Americans across the country received harmful hate messages via text after the election. The communication industry has been trying to figure out how it happened. (Image credit: Daniel Hertzberg for NPR)

Title: Israel's Netanyahu heads to U.S. to meet with Trump
Description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Sunday he will discuss 'victory over Hamas,' countering Iran and expanding diplomatic relations with Arab countries in his meeting with President Trump. (Image credit: Maya Alleruzzo)

Title: D.C. crash investigators focus on altitude and vision quality of helicopter crew
Description: Investigators are still working to piece together key details to determine the cause of the crash that killed 67 people. (Image credit: Samuel Corum)

Title: Elon Musk's X sues Lego, Nestlé and more brands, accusing them of advertising boycott
Description: The new defendants added into the legal filing included Lego, Nestlé, Tyson Foods, Abbott Laboratories, Colgate-Palmolive, Pinterest and Shell International. (Image credit: Al Drago)

Title: Trump says airstrikes on ISIS in Somalia killed terrorists without 'harming civilians'
Description: In a Truth Social post Saturday, President Trump announced successful precision airstrikes on the 'Senior ISIS Attack Planner,' though didn't provide a name for that individual. (Image credit: AP)

Title: 7 dead, 19 injured after a small medical plane crashes in Philadelphia
Description: A small plane crashed near a shopping center in northeast Philadelphia on Friday night. The aircraft was carrying a child patient who received medical treatment and was returning home to Mexico. (Image credit: Kyle Mazza)

Title: Trump fires chief of the federal consumer watchdog agency
Description: Rohit Chopra had led the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau since 2021. Consumer groups praised his leadership, while Republicans have frequently attacked the agency. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Democrats will choose new party leadership today
Description: Without control of the White House or Congress, the new DNC chair will lead the campaign arm of a Democratic Party that is still figuring out how to move on from rejection at the ballot box. (Image credit: Brynn Anderson)

Title: Medical transport plane with 6 people aboard crashes in Philadelphia, kills all aboard
Description: An air ambulance with six people aboard crashed and then exploded on Friday evening in Philadelphia. The medical transport plane was returning a patient and her mother to Mexico. Several houses caught on fire close to the crash site. Six people on the ground were taken to the hospital with injuries.

Title: How a funding freeze ordered by Trump is impacting 2 early-career scientists
Description: With a sudden freeze of funding, two scientists find their livelihoods and futures upended.

Title: Congolese foreign minister discusses the humanitarian situation and what the US can do
Description: NPR's Scott Simon asks Thérèse Kayikwamba Wagner, the Congolese minister for foreign affairs, about gains made by rebels backed by Rwanda.

Title: NTSB recovers black box from Army helicopter that crashed into American Airlines jet
Description: Transportation officials have restricted helicopter flights around Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport after Wednesday's mid-air collision between an Army helicopter and an American Airlines jet.

Title: Three things to know about Rubio's first international trip
Description: Marco Rubio heads to Latin America on his first trip as secretary of state, including Panama, where President Trump wants control of the canal. (Image credit: Evan Vucci)

Title: Palestinians worry about what Netanyahu's visit to the White House signals for Gaza
Description: NPR's Scott Simons speaks to Maha Nassar, a professor at the University of Arizona, about how Palestinians will view the Israeli Prime Minister's visit to the White House next week.

Title: An earnest defense of America's silliest holiday: Groundhog Day
Description: Let's celebrate Groundhog Day, in all its bizarre, quirky strangeness. Let it remind us that we have not subdued nature, but merely made ourselves more comfortable in its domain. (Image credit: Brett Carlsen)

Title: Former German President Horst Köhler dies at 81
Description: Köhler, a onetime head of the International Monetary Fund who became a popular German president before resigning abruptly in a flap over comments about the country's military, has died at 81. (Image credit: Martial Trezzini)

Title: A U.S. dual citizen is among 3 Israeli hostages exchanged for Palestinian prisoners
Description: Siegel is the first American to be released as part of this deal. A total of 18 hostages have been released since the ceasefire took effect. Hundreds Palestinians have been released so far. (Image credit: AFP)

Title: Plane with at least 2 aboard crashes in Philadelphia, sets homes ablaze
Description: A medical transport jet crashed in Philadelphia on Friday about 30 seconds after taking off, unleashing a fireball into the night sky and rattling residents after the second U.S. air disaster in as many days. (Image credit: Matt Rourke)

Title: Map: A look at helicopter traffic patterns over D.C.
Description: The airspace above Reagan National Airport, where a commercial plane collided with an Army helicopter this week, has become increasingly congested with air traffic, including helicopters.

Title: Oscar-nominated actress Karla Sofía Gascón apologizes for old social media posts
Description: The first openly trans actress to be nominated for an Oscar is facing backlash for old social media posts that denigrate certain marginalized groups. She apologized for the posts through a statement. (Image credit: Etienne Laurent)

Title: Rwandan-Backed Rebels Strengthen Hold in Eastern Congo
Description: Rebel forces continue to claim more Congolese territory coveted for its rich mineral resources. In Myanmar, former leader and Nobel laureate Aung San Suu Kyi remains jailed and the country is mired in a brutal civil war.

Title: 5 things to know about the fighting in the Democratic Republic of Congo
Description: Rwandan-backed M23 rebels say they are now in control of the key eastern Congolese city of Goma. Their fighters continue to claim more territory in one of the world's most mineral-rich territories. (Image credit: Brian Inganga)

Title: Texas is Trump's biggest – and most enthusiastic – partner on immigration overhaul
Description: Gov. Greg Abbott this week directed state agencies to work with federal immigration authorities to crack down on illegal immigration. (Image credit: Anadolu/Anadolu via Getty Images)

Title: The latest in the DCA plane crash investigation
Description: Investigators are piecing together why a passenger jet and military helicopter collided in the skies near Washington, D.C., killing all 67 on board both aircraft.

Title: FAA restricts helicopter flights near DCA airport after mid-air collision
Description: Federal authorities have restricted helicopter flights near Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. The move comes days after a deadly collision between a passenger jet and a military helicopter. (Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)

Title: The D.C.-area crash recalls some of the deadliest aircraft disasters in U.S. history
Description: Responders are working to recover the victims of Wednesday night's midair collision over Washington, D.C. It could be the deadliest crash to occur in U.S. airspace in at least 15 years. (Image credit: Ed Reinke)

Title: Costco raises pay above $30 an hour for many, as Teamsters threatens strike
Description: Costco is raising pay for most workers as Friday night deadline looms on a new contract with its unionized employees. (Image credit: Gene J. Puskar)

Title: Investigation into the fatal plane-helicopter crash. And, future of nuclear testing
Description: The next steps in the fatal midair plane and helicopter crash investigation. And, why nuclear testing could ramp up in the U.S., as well as a look inside the secret lab where weapons testing happens. (Image credit: Petty Officer 2nd Class Taylor B/U.S. Coast Guard)

Title: Trump wants to cut the federal workforce. Who they are and what that means
Description: President Trump's efforts to cut the federal workforce by 10% might not save as much money as hoped and could have unintended consequences. NPR explains why. (Image credit: Mark Schiefelbein)

Title: Former FAA official discusses safety concerns over crowded airspace around D.C.
Description: NPR speaks with Michael McCormick, former vice president of the FAA Air Traffic Organization, about reports that the airspace above Reagan airport has long raised safety concerns.

Title: 8 things to know about Groundhog Day and its big star, Punxsutawney Phil
Description: The weather-predicting groundhog celebrity has met two presidents and drinks a life-extending elixir: 'Our Phil is like, probably 139 years old,' Groundhog Club Inner Circle President Tom Dunkel says. (Image credit: Jeff Swensen)

Title: What is RFK Jr.'s favorite bird? Why is this woman smiling? Find out in the quiz!
Description: This week was hard on the conflict-averse. But if you're up on nursery rhymes, prehistoric bodily fluids and Renaissance art, you'll get at least three right this week.

Title: Editor's note: Reporting the midair collision will focus on facts and people's stories
Description: NPR's reporting will continue to focus on what happened and learning what we can about the victims and telling their stories. (Image credit: Petty Officer 2nd Class Taylor B/U.S. Coast Guard)

Description: Video footage of the incident shows the aircraft flying at a low altitude, before an explosion happened at the moment of impact. The National Transportation Safety Board is investigating.

Description: Latest on the deadly midair collision in the D.C. area, national debate erupts in Germany over letting extreme elements into mainstream politics, inside U.S.'s program to maintain its nuclear weapons.

Title: Wichita residents grieve after plane collision disaster near Washington, D.C.
Description: Residents in Wichita are grieving after a commercial plane coming from the Kansas city collided with a helicopter near Washington, D.C. All 67 people on both aircraft are believed to have died.

Title: How do insurance companies determine the value of homes destroyed by wildfires?
Description: Before people who lost their homes in the Los Angeles wildfires can rebuild, they need money. But how does an insurance company figure what a house is worth when there's nothing left standing?

Title: Boston ice skating club reeling after several members killed in D.C.-area plane crash
Description: A storied Massachusetts skating club lost several members and coaches to the plane crash near Washington, D.C. The club was also affected by the 1961 crash that killed the U.S. Olympic skating team.

Title: President Trump threatens to impose steep tariffs on Canada and Mexico
Description: President Trump is threatening to impose tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico as early as this weekend. Some businesses are trying to prepare, while many economists hope it's just a threat.

Title: LA firefighter tells woman he saved 30 years ago that she helped him in tough times
Description: Nearly 30 years after carrying her out of a burning building, Los Angeles County firefighter Derek Bart tells the woman he saved, Myeshia Oates, 'You've carried me through tough times.'

Title: False reports about immigration enforcement flood social media, causing many to worry
Description: People without legal status in the U.S. are worried about the Trump administration's ramped up immigration enforcement. And false reports about immigration raids are causing some to panic.

Title: Hear the latest on the deadly collision between a plane and helicopter near D.C.
Description: The head of the National Transportation Safety Board is promising a thorough investigation into the deadly midair collision between a passenger plane and an Army helicopter near Washington, D.C.

Title: Study finds India doubled its tiger population in a decade
Description: The study found that some local communities near tiger habitats have also benefited from the increase in tigers because of the foot traffic and revenues brought in by ecotourism. (Image credit: Satyajeet Singh Rathore)

Title: A New Zealand mountain is granted personhood, recognizing it as sacred for Māori
Description: The recognition acknowledges the mountain's theft from the Māori after New Zealand was colonized. It fulfills an agreement from the country's government to Indigenous people. (Image credit: Dita Alangkara)

Title: RFK Jr., Trump's pick for HHS, grilled about vaccines again in Day 2 hearing
Description: More dramatic questioning on vaccines in RFK Jr's second confirmation hearing. Bond/Simmons-Duffin/Stone/Webber (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: Questions about helicopter's path could prove key in Pentagon probe of midair crash
Description: Among the unanswered questions about the crash near Washington, D.C., are the flight pattern of the Black Hawk helicopter and the exact nature of its training exercise. (Image credit: Al Drago)

Title: Norway's Electric-Vehicle Milestone
Description: 9 out of ten cars sold in Norway are EV's. Government incentives and a commitment to charging stations have made Norway a world leader in electric vehicle use. (Image credit: Bloomberg)

Title: FDA upgrades recall of Lay's potato chips to most serious level
Description: The problem ingredient identified was 'undeclared milk,' which poses a risk to those with severe sensitivities or allergies. (Image credit: Justin Sullivan)

Title: Map: See the aircraft's paths before they collided near Washington, D.C.
Description: Investigators say there are likely no survivors in the deadly aircraft collision that occurred Wednesday evening above the icy waters of the Potomac river. (Image credit: Al Drago)

Description: Residents and officials of Wichita, Kan., react to the crash of the commercial flight that left Wichita and collided with a military helicopter Wednesday at Regan National Airport in Washington, D.C.

Title: Rwandan-backed rebels take control of Goma
Description: Rwandan-backed rebels declare they are now in control of the key eastern Congolese city of Goma, as their troops continue to claim more territory in the mineral rich region.

Description: Investigators are trying to understand why an Army Black Hawk helicopter and American Airlines regional jet collided in mid-air near Washington, D.C. Sixty-seven people were aboard the two aircraft.

Title: Air traffic controller radio offers look into lead-up to midair crash
Description: It will be some time before investigators can offer clear answers to the cause of the midair crash at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport but air traffic controller audio and radar reviewed by NPR offer some insight into what happened before. (Image credit: Carolyn Kaster)

Title: Olympian Nancy Kerrigan reacts tearfully to skaters' deaths in airline collision
Description: Several members of U.S. Figure Skating were on the American Airlines flight, including members of the Skating Club of Boston. The club held a press conference which included club alum Nancy Kerrigan.

Title: FAA data shows 30 near-misses at Reagan Airport
Description: A commercial flight hit a military helicopter at Washington, D.C.'s Ronald Reagan National Airport Wednesday night. The airport has a history of crashes and near-misses going back decades. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Near-collisions at Reagan National Airport often involve military aircraft
Description: A commercial flight hit a military helicopter at Washington, D.C.'s Ronald Reagan National Airport Wednesday night. The FAA tracks near-collisions at all U.S. airports.

Title: Crowded airspace has been a concern at Reagan National Airport. Here is what to know.
Description: Lawmakers have expressed concerns about congestion in at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport amid a constricted space. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Former FAA administrator and airline pilot provides analysis on midair collision in D.C. area
Description: Steve Inskeep speaks with former Federal Aviation Administrator Randy Babbitt about the midair collision in Washington, D.C.

Title: What we know about the midair crash near Washington, D.C.
Description: Authorities believe there were no survivors in the accident, which happened as a regional passenger jet was attempting to land Wednesday night at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport. (Image credit: Kayla Bartkowski)

Title: U.S. and Russian figure skaters are among the victims of the D.C.-area plane crash
Description: The plane that crashed near Washington, D.C., was carrying an unknown number of passengers from the figure skating community, including Russian husband-and-wife world champions. (Image credit: Chris Cole)

Title: Plane, Black Hawk helicopter collide near D.C. And, Trump's plans for Guantánamo
Description: An American Airlines plane and a Black Hawk helicopter collided near Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport last night. And, President Trump plans to use Guantánamo as a waystation for deportees. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Authorities believe there are no survivors after a midair crash in Washington, D.C.
Description: Authorities in Washington, D.C., say they believe no one survived a midair collision between a regional airliner and a U.S. Army helicopter.

Title: 3 Israeli and 5 Thai hostages freed in Gaza in exchange for Palestinian prisoners
Description: The exchange is part of a deal between Israel and Hamas that will see a total of 33 hostages returned to Israel in exchange for around 1,900 Palestinian prisoners and detainees. (Image credit: Mostafa Alkharouf)

Title: After fires, LA students yearn to get back to school, and a normal life
Description: The historic fires in Los Angeles meant many students lost homes, schools, or both. Now, as some schools reopen, families are trying to find routine. (Image credit: Jireh Deng for NPR)

Title: Trans community fears Trump's actions will upend legal precedent on prison protections
Description: One of President Trump's first executive orders impacts transgender inmates incarcerated in federal facilities. It's just one in a series of actions signed by Trump that target the trans community. (Image credit: Ben Curtis)

Title: Trump's pick for intel chief, Tulsi Gabbard, faces her confirmation hearing
Description: Among the topics likely to come up at the hearing: her 2017 meeting with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, her friendly positions toward Russia and her push to drop charges against Edward Snowden. (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: Trump's FBI director pick, Kash Patel, faces confirmation hearing
Description: Kash Patel, President Trump's pick to run the FBI, answers questions Thursday in a public hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Description: Dozens of Jan. 6 defendants who received pardons from President Trump had past criminal convictions for charges including rape, manslaughter, domestic violence and drug trafficking. (Image credit: Julio Cortez)

Description: Rescuers search for survivors after midair collision in D.C. area, Trump plans to hold criminal migrants deported from U.S. at Gitmo, some pardoned Jan. 6 rioters have lengthy criminal records.

Description: A regional jet with 64 people aboard collided in midair with an Army Black Hawk helicopter as it was approaching a runway at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport on Wednesday night.

Description: Legal centers across the country are preparing migrants without legal status for various scenarios as the Trump administration tries to ramp up immigration raids, detentions and deportations.

Description: Canada accounts for about 60% of U.S. crude oil imports. If Trump's tariffs end up applying to that oil, that would likely cause gas prices to rise in the U.S., Canada's ambassador warns. (Image credit: David Zalubowski)

Title: Trump plans to hold up to 30,000 criminal migrants deported from the U.S. at Gitmo
Description: President Trump says he plans to use a migrant holding facility at the U.S. naval base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to house up to 30,000 criminal migrants deported from the United States.President Trump says he plans to use a migrant holding facility at the U.S. naval base in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, to house up to 30,000 criminal migrants deported from the United States.

Title: Immigrant couple in Chicago plans for potential deportation scenarios
Description: An undocumented couple in Chicago, whose baby is a U.S. citizen, prepare for potential deportation and plan to keep the family together no matter what President Trump does.

Title: Aviation safety consultant provides latest analysis on midair collision in D.C. area
Description: We get analysis from an aviation safety consultant on the midair collision between an American Airlines plane and Army Black Hawk helicopter on Wednesday night in the Washington, D.C. area.

Description: President Trump's order to suspend foreign aid is impacting Afghanistan, where anxiety over food supplies have partly pushed up prices. The Taliban says dozens of charities have had to halt work.

Description: The Los Angeles wildfires have many cities asking whether it's safe to build new housing in risky areas. But limiting construction is tough when there's a housing shortage.

Title: Trump order cracks down on antisemitism and could deport foreign student protesters
Description: The executive order directs government agencies to use all available tools to prosecute or remove perpetrators of antisemitic harassment and violence, especially on college campuses. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Trump says U.S. will send 'worst criminal illegal aliens' to Guantánamo Bay
Description: The president says up to 30,000 criminal migrants deported from the United States could be housed at the facility in Cuba, but it wasn't immediately clear how the plan would be implemented. (Image credit: Ramon Espinosa)

Title: American Airlines plane, Blackhawk helicopter collide midair near D.C.-area airport
Description: Radar tracking sites show the passenger jet appears to have fallen into the frigid Potomac River. Officials at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport say all takeoffs and landings were halted. (Image credit: Ting Shen)

Title: Greenland, Still Not For Sale. And the Mona Lisa Gets Its Own Room.
Description: Even if Greenland were for sale, buying the Artic territory would be complicated. And French President Emmanuel Macron promises to renovate the Louvre, which is falling into disrepair.

Description: The president directed several departments to submit plans for using federal funds to expand school choice. (Image credit: Jim Watson)

Title: The future of passports with the X gender marker
Description: As the state department freeze passport applications with the X gender markers, what are the implications for both current and future passport holders?

Title: Visiting a Russian air base to see how Moscow will fare after the fall of the regime
Description: Russia lost a key ally when the Syrian President was ousted by Islamist rebels last month. NPR visited a Russian air base in western Syria to examine how Moscow will fare under Syria's new rulers.

Title: Trans servicemember says 'we will do the best we can' amid Trump proposed military ban
Description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with Col. Bree Fram, an openly transgender member of the U.S. Space Force, about President Trump's calls to remove transgender service members from the military.

Title: On the ground in Gaza: Red Cross' role in hostage and prisoner exchanges
Description: As prisoner and hostage exchanges happen in Gaza, we hear about the International Red Cross's experience in facilitating this work.

Title: Trump's pick for Commerce Secretary is Howard Lutnick. Here's what to know
Description: The billionaire Wall Street CEO fielded questions about tariffs, China's AI progress, broadband access, allegiance to Trump and the revival of American mining and semiconductor production. (Image credit: Rod Lamkey)

Title: As global tensions rise, so do fears of new nuclear testing
Description: For nearly 30 years, the world's major powers have observed a voluntary moratorium on nuclear testing. But with tensions rising around the globe, some fear that could soon change.

Title: Photos: Celebrations commence the Year of the Snake
Description: For many, the Lunar New Year is a time to reflect on people they have lost. But it's also a time to set intentions and welcome the new energy of the future. (Image credit: Greg Baker/AFP)

Title: Trump ends extension of temporary protected status for hundreds of thousands of Venezuelan migrants
Description: The move to revoke the extension of temporary protected status would make hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans eligible for deportation. (Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)

Title: Trump's Mideast envoy visits Gaza before meeting with Netanyahu
Description: Steve Witkoff helped negotiate the Israel-Hamas ceasefire deal. His visit to Gaza pn Wednesday was the first by a senior U.S. official in more than a decade. (Image credit: Hasan Eslayeh)

Title: Hegseth strips Milley of his security detail, orders investigation into his conduct
Description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has ordered an investigation into retired general Mark Milley — who often clashed with President Trump — and determine whether he should be reduced in rank. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker)

Title: Ahmed al-Sharaa, who toppled Assad, is named Syria's interim president
Description: Sharaa was already de facto head of Syria's government ever since a coalition of rebel fighters swept through most of Syria and ousted Assad's regime. (Image credit: Ali Haj Suleiman)

Title: New York becomes the first state to close schools for Lunar New Year
Description: It's the first time New York students will have the day off for the Lunar New Year since a new state law was signed in 2023. In 2024, the holiday fell on a Saturday. (Image credit: Michael M. Santiago)

Title: Trump signs first bill of his second presidency, the Laken Riley Act, into law
Description: The bill is named for a Georgia nursing student who was killed last year by a Venezuelan man without legal status who had a criminal record. (Image credit: Pedro Ugarte)

Title: DOJ asks to dismiss case of 2 men indicted for allegedly helping Trump hide documents
Description: The DOJ asked a federal court to dismiss its case against two men indicted for allegedly helping Trump conceal classified documents. Prosecutors dropped Trump from the case after his election win. (Image credit: Anna Moneymaker/Getty; Rebecca Blackwell/AP)

Title: Fearing encounters with ICE, tribal leaders offer guidance to their members
Description: Tribal leaders are advising members on what to do if they're approached by federal law enforcement. The guidance follows what tribal leaders call concerning encounters with immigration officials. (Image credit: Alex Brandon)

Title: The Doomsday Clock has never been closer to metaphorical midnight. What does it mean?

Title: Two ways Trump aims to reshape government. And, how U.S. children are doing in school
Description: President Trump's actions this week reveal his broad effort to reshape the federal government. And, the new Nation's Report Card shows the pandemic's impact on education nearly five years later. (Image credit: Kent Nishimura)

Title: RFK Jr. says he'll fix the overdose crisis. Critics say his plan is risky
Description: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. survived heroin addiction and says that if confirmed as head of the Department of Health and Human Services, he'll build treatment 'farms' to help people recover. (Image credit: John Nacion)

Title: 66 million years ago, a fish chewed up and spit out food. It's now a fossil in Denmark
Description: The fossil was found at a cliff in Denmark. Fossilized vomit is called regurgitalite, and it's a type of trace fossil, which tells scientists about an organism's daily life. (Image credit: Sten Lennart Jakobsen)

Title: Step inside the secret lab where America tests its nukes
Description: A thousand feet beneath the desert, the United States conducts experiments to verify that its weapons work. But some fear a live test could come soon.

Title: Nearly 5 years after schools closed, the nation gets a new report card
Description: There's some good news in math, mostly bad news in reading and lots of questions about why students are still struggling. (Image credit: Newsday LLC)

Title: New Orleans clears homeless encampments near stadium ahead of Super Bowl
Description: As New Orleans prepares to host the Super Bowl, state authorities have moved people from homeless encampments near the stadium to a temporary shelter. Advocates aren't happy with how it went down.

Title: Homeless encampments near stadium in New Orleans removed ahead of Super Bowl
Description: As New Orleans prepares to host the Super Bowl, state authorities have moved people from homeless encampments near the stadium to a temporary shelter. Advocates aren't happy with how it went down.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Trump trying to dramatically reshape federal government, RFK Jr. faces Senate confirmation hearings for HHS secretary, national assessment on reading and math shows students struggling post-pandemic.

Title: U.N. warns that Democratic Republic of Congo conflict could spill into regional war
Description: In the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwandan-backed rebels have overrun the city of Goma, sparking concerns at the U.N. of a wider regional war.

Title: Martin Gordon, Anglican bishop of Goma, calls for peace in the DRC
Description: NPR's Michel Martin speaks with Martin Gordon, the Anglican bishop of Goma, who fled before rebels advanced into the city in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Today, he is issuing a call for peace.

Title: Late revered French Catholic priest Abbé Pierre accused of sexual abuse
Description: Revered French Catholic priest and humanitarian Abbé Pierre has been accused of rape and sexual assault nearly 20 years after his death, leading France to grapple with his legacy.

Title: Several people are feared dead in a stampede at massive festival in India

Title: Why members of two of EPA's influential science advisory committees were let go

Description: After the ouster of Syria's longtime leader Bashar al-Assad last month, Israel's military has taken up a new post in the demilitarized buffer zone created in Syria after the 1973 Arab-Israeli war. (Image credit: Ayman Oghanna for NPR)

Description: Lee Gelernt with the ACLU said the action goes 'way beyond anything that even President Trump has tried in the past.' (Image credit: Guillermo Arias)

Title: Couples wed as landmark same-sex marriage law takes effect in Thailand
Description: Hundreds of same-sex couples tied the knot across Thailand on Thursday, as the country becomes the first in Southeast Asia to legally recognize equal marriage. (Image credit: Chanakarn Laosarakham)

Title: This economist survived a wildfire. Now she's taking on California's insurance crisis
Description: An economist's harrowing escape from fire, and her big ideas to rescue California from its insurance doom spiral. (Image credit: San Francisco Chronicle/Hearst Newspapers)

Title: Postcards From The Border aims to challenge dominant portrayal of U.S.-Mexico border
Description: Challenging perceptions of the US-Mexico border: A new Texas art project uses music, photos and storytelling to highlight the the rich cultural tapestry beyond headlines of migration and enforcement (Image credit: Joel Salcido)

Title: In a surprise, U.S. colleges saw higher enrollment last fall
Description: The number of students in undergraduate and graduate programs rose above pre-pandemic levels for the first time. (Image credit: The Washington Post)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Congress passes immigration enforcement bill in Trump's first legislative win, federal health officials told to stop all public communications, and the Oscar nominations are announced.

Title: Sheriff Chuck Jenkins of Frederick County in Maryland ready to assist in deportations
Description: President Trump campaigned on a promise to carry out the largest-ever deportation of migrants in the U.S illegally. Chuck Jenkins, sheriff of Frederick County in Maryland, says he is ready to assist.

Title: NPR's Renee Montagne is retiring after more than 40 years in public radio
Description: Renee Montagne co-hosted Morning Edition for a dozen years, and after more than 40 years in public radio, she is retiring.

Title: Why the idea of buying Greenland is more complicated now than it once might have been
Description: President Trump says he wants the U.S. to take 'ownership' of Greenland. Description: County governments often play an essential role in providing health care services for older adults. However more counties, like one in Wisconsin, hope to get out of the nursing home business and let private operators take over

Title: Japan's Mingei art movement is having a revival as it turns 100 years old
Description: Japan's century-old Mingei, or folk art, movement celebrates the everyday work of anonymous artists. It stands in contrast to both fine arts and industrially mass-produced goods. And it's having a yet another revival.

Title: Is Trump's order to allow TikTok to continue operating in the U.S. even legal?
Description: TikTok is still running thanks to an order by President Trump. It was banned in a law passed and upheld with rare speed by all branches of government. So what's his authority under the law to do that?

Title: President Trump wants remote federal workers back in their offices
Description: President Trump signed an executive memorandum telling federal agencies to bring their workers back to the office. Harvard Business School's Raj Choudhury talks about what research says of the move.

Title: We The People: Cruel and Unusual Punishment
Description: The Eighth Amendment. What is cruel and unusual punishment? Who gets to define and decide its boundaries? And how did the Constitution's authors imagine it might change? Today on Throughline's We the People: the Eighth Amendment, the death penalty, and what cruel and unusual really means.To access bonus episodes and listen to Throughline sponsor-free, subscribe to Throughline+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org/throughline.

Title: U.N. chief warns gangs could overrun Haiti's capital without additional support
Description: U.N. Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said in a report that gangs in Haiti could overrun the capital, leading to a complete breakdown of government, without additional international support. (Image credit: Jean Feguens Regala)

Title: Trump's Jan. 6 pardons have historians concerned about tolerance of political violence
Description: Trump's pardon of nearly all of the people convicted of crimes in relation to Jan. 6 was no surprise to those who followed his campaign promises. But for some historians, it sends a troubling signal.

Title: Prince Harry and Rupert Murdoch's British tabloids settle
Description: Prince Harry settled a long-running legal case against Rupert Murdoch's British tabloids over privacy invasions after the media company issued a full-throated apology.

Title: Bishop Mariann Budde tells NPR 'I won't apologize' for sermon addressing Trump
Description: The Episcopal bishop of Washington spoke with NPR to discuss her sermon addressing President Trump and why she asked him to have mercy. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: Some Altadena homes survived the fires, but it's unclear if they're safe to return to
Description: Angelenos whose homes were spared by the fires -- but close enough to be full of ash and soot -- are concerned about whether their homes will ever be safe to live in.

Title: Churches, schools are no longer off limits to agents rounding up undocumented migrants
Description: The Trump administration says it will no longer consider churches and schools off limits to agents tracking down and arresting migrants without legal status.

Title: Pete Hegseth's views about women and military standards
Description: Pete Hegseth has said that the military has lowered standards to include women in combat. Advocates say they have fought against similar claims since all combat positions were opened to women in 2015.

Title: Israel said it wouldn't let Hamas rule Gaza. The ceasefire is here and Hamas remains
Description: Israel said repeatedly that it wouldn't allow Hamas to run Gaza in the future. Yet Hamas remains the strongest force in Gaza and Israel has never offered a plausible alternative.

Title: DOJ threatens to prosecute local officials for resisting immigration enforcement
Description: In a new memo, a Justice Department official seeks to realign the department's positions on immigration with President Trump's executive actions — and threatens local officials who don't cooperate. (Image credit: Pool)

Title: Does Hamas Still Rule Gaza?
Description: Israel vowed to remove Hamas from power when it went to war in Gaza, following the attacks on Israel in October, 2023. With a temporary ceasefire in place we're able to see if they've reached that goal and it seems Hamas is still deeply entrenched in Gaza. We'll hear more about who is taking charge as the dust settles and what the future of governance in the territory might be.

Title: Is there an American oligarchy?
Description: When Donald Trump was sworn in on Monday, he was flanked by billionaires Elon Musk, Jeff Bezos and Mark Zuckerberg.Also on the dais was Apple CEO Tim Cook, Open AI's CEO Sam Altman, and Bernard Arnault owner of L-V-M-H which owns luxury brands like Dior and Louis Vuitton. An American government closely aligned with money and power is something outgoing President Joe Biden warned about in his farewell address. Oligarchy – A word that once more commonly referred to the super wealthy of Eastern Europe has reached the shores of the U.S. What could an American oligarchy mean for the U.S. government and its citizens For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus....

Title: The waiting stinks, but Sydney may soon enjoy the aroma of its 'corpse flower'
Description: The flower's Latin name translates as 'giant, misshapen penis.' But it's better known to locals as 'Putricia.' Royal Botanical Garden Sydney has even set up a livestream in anticipation. (Image credit: Lisa Maree Williams)

Title: When Ichiro retired, his records felt 'small' compared to the emotional moments
Description: Ichiro Suzuki's career was full of hitting streaks, All-Star Games and Gold Glove awards. But all that paled compared to moments with fans like his farewell at the Tokyo Dome in 2019, he said. (Image credit: Steph Chambers)

Title: Trump threatens Russia with tariffs and sanctions if it does not agree to end war
Description: It is unclear how much impact economic penalties would have on the Russian government, since they already face various sanctions imposed by the previous administration. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Another casualty of Israel's war in Lebanon: Efforts to save endangered turtles
Description: Lebanese volunteers are anxious to get back to sea turtle conservation on southern beaches that were off-limits to civilians when fighting escalated between Israel and Hezbollah. (Image credit: Tamara Saade for NPR)

Title: Prince Harry settles with Murdoch's British tabloids as trial is about to begin
Description: Prince Harry has agreed to settle his lawsuit against Rupert Murdoch's British tabloids. The deal ends a years' long battle to hold the newspapers accountable for invasions of privacy. (Image credit: Frank Augstein/AP)

Description: Southern California was forecast to face more dangerous winds on Wednesday, but could get some badly needed rain this weekend, which could create new challenges like toxic ash runoff. (Image credit: Gregory Bull)

Description: A winter storm prompted a National Weather Service office in Louisiana to issue a first-ever blizzard warning. The storm is causing dangerous conditions from Texas to North Carolina. (Image credit: Gerald Herbert)

Description: A fire raged through a popular ski resort south of Istanbul early Tuesday. The deadly fire broke out during a school holiday when the area's hotels are packed. (Image credit: IHA)

Title: Trump's pick for U.N. ambassador is Elise Stefanik. Here's what to know
Description: Elise Stefanik was a key defender of then-President Donald Trump during his impeachment proceedings and she later grilled university presidents over what she described as antisemitism. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Murdoch's News Corp offers Prince Harry settlement to resolve years-long lawsuit

Title: Trump is back and ready to change America

And, unlike last time, he narrowly won the popular vote.And Trump is prepared to exercise his new power almost immediately. He's pledged to sign an unprecedented wave of executive actions – many of which will be challenged in court.These actions include one making it U.S. policy to recognize only two biologically distinct sexes – male and female. Description: As President Trump takes office he inherits two international conflicts in which the United States is deeply involved. On the campaign trail he said he would be able to end the war between Russia and Ukraine. Last month he said there would be 'hell to pay' if Hamas and Israel did not reach a ceasefire and hostage release deal before he assumed office. A temporary and fragile ceasefire began on Sunday.
